name: Audit-Organization-1
description: This Organization resource represents the information needed for the JSON Web Token.
copyright: Copyright Â© 2016 Health and Social Care Information Centre

element.short: This Organization resource represents the information needed for the JSON Web Token.
element.definition: A formally or informally recognized grouping of people or organizations formed for the purpose of achieving some form of collective action.  Includes companies, institutions, corporations, departments, community groups, healthcare practice groups, etc.

constraint.human: The organization SHALL at least have a name or an id, and possibly more than one

element.short: ODS code to identify the organisation at organisation level
element.definition: Identifier for the organization that is used to identify the organization across multiple disparate systems.
element.requirements: Organizations are known by a variety of ids. Some institutions maintain several, and most collect identifiers for exchange with other organizations concerning the organization.

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comments: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labelled as UserSelected = true.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: The namespace for the identifier
element.definition: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
element.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers.  To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular sequence or set of unique identifiers.
element.exampleUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the Identifier.value itself is a full uri

element.short: The value that is unique
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comments: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comments: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
element.comments: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

element.short: Text alternative for the resource
element.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: Whether the organization's record is still in active use
element.definition: Whether the organization's record is still in active use.
element.comments: Default is true.
element.requirements: Need a flag to indicate a record is no longer to be used and should generally be hidden for the user in the UI.

mapping.map: ./Status (however this concept in ServD more covers why the organization is active or not, could be delisted, deregistered, not operational yet) this could alternatively be derived from ./StartDate and ./EndDate and given a context date.

element.short: The kind of organization that this is.
element.definition: The kind of organization that this is.
element.comments: Organizations can be corporations, wards, sections, clinical teams, government departments, etc. Note that code is generally a classifier of the type of organization; in many applications, codes are used to identity a particular organization (say, ward) as opposed to another of the same type - these are identifiers, not codes.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the kind of organization that this is - different organization types have different uses.

element.short: A code taken from the organisation type list of codes.
element.definition: A code taken from the organisation type list of codes.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the terminology system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the terminology system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: Name used for the organization associated with the ODS code
element.definition: Name used for the organization associated with the ODS code.
element.requirements: Need to use the name as the label of the organization.

element.short: A contact detail for the organization
element.definition: A contact detail for the organization
element.comments: The use code home is not to be used. Note that these contacts are not the contact details of people who are employed by or represent the organization, but official contacts for the organization itself.
element.requirements: Human contact for the organization

constraint.human: The telecom of an organization can never be of use 'home'

element.short: phone | fax | email | pager | other
element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.

element.short: The actual contact point details
element.definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comments: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
element.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

element.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

element.short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. Contacts are ranked with lower values coming before higher values.
element.comments: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

element.short: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

element.short: An address for the organization
element.definition: An address for the organization
element.comments: Organization may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods. The use code home is not to be used.
element.requirements: May need to keep track of the organization's addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements.

constraint.human: An address of an organization can never be of use 'home'

mapping.map: No authoritative equivalent in V2.x; some V2.x segments such as OBX might provide a serialized instance value

element.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

element.short: postal | physical | both
element.definition: Distinguishes between physical addresses (those you can visit) and mailing addresses (e.g. PO Boxes and care-of addresses). Most addresses are both.

binding.description: The type of an address (physical / postal)

element.short: Text representation of the address
element.definition: A full text representation of the address
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc.
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.short: Name of city, town etc.
element.definition: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.

element.short: District name (aka county)
element.definition: The name of the administrative area (county).
element.comments: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' in used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.

element.short: Sub-unit of country (abbreviations ok)
element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).

element.short: Postal code for area
element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.

element.short: Country (can be ISO 3166 3 letter code)
element.definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
element.comments: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.

element.short: Time period when address was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when address was/is in use.
element.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

element.short: The organization of which this organization forms a part
element.definition: The organization of which this organization forms a part.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the hierarchy of organizations within an organization.

element.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
element.comments: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

element.short: Text alternative for the resource
element.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose
element.definition: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose.
element.comments: Where multiple contacts for the same purpose are provided there is a standard extension that can be used to determine which one is the preferred contact to use.
element.requirements: Need to keep track of assigned contact points within bigger organization.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: The type of contact
element.definition: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached.
element.requirements: Need to distinguish between multiple contact persons.

binding.description: The purpose for which you would contact a contact party

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labelled as UserSelected = true.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: A name associated with the contact
element.definition: A name associated with the contact.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the person by name.

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.

binding.description: The use of a human name

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: A full text representation of the name.
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and structured parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

element.short: Family name (often called 'Surname')
element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comments: For family name, hyphenated names such as "Smith-Jones" are a single name, but names with spaces such as "Smith Jones" are broken into multiple parts.

element.short: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
element.definition: Given name.
element.comments: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name.  Not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.

element.short: Parts that come before the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.

element.short: Parts that come after the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

element.short: Contact details (telephone, email, etc.)  for a contact
element.definition: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the party may be contacted.
element.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

element.short: phone | fax | email | pager | other
element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.

element.short: The actual contact point details
element.definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comments: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
element.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

element.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

element.short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. Contacts are ranked with lower values coming before higher values.
element.comments: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

element.short: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

element.short: Visiting or postal addresses for the contact
element.definition: Visiting or postal addresses for the contact.
element.requirements: May need to keep track of a contact party's address for contacting, billing or reporting requirements.

element.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

element.short: postal | physical | both
element.definition: Distinguishes between physical addresses (those you can visit) and mailing addresses (e.g. PO Boxes and care-of addresses). Most addresses are both.

binding.description: The type of an address (physical / postal)

element.short: Text representation of the address
element.definition: A full text representation of the address.
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.
element.exampleString: 1, Main Street, Leeds, West Yorkshire, LS1 3PO

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc.
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.short: Name of city, town etc.
element.definition: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.

element.short: District name (aka county)
element.definition: The name of the administrative area (county).
element.comments: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' in used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.

element.short: Sub-unit of country (abbreviations ok)
element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).

element.short: Postal code for area
element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.

element.short: Country (can be ISO 3166 3 letter code)
element.definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
element.comments: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.

element.short: Time period when address was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when address was/is in use.
element.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

element.short: This Organization resource represents the information needed for the JSON Web Token.
element.definition: A formally or informally recognized grouping of people or organizations formed for the purpose of achieving some form of collective action.  Includes companies, institutions, corporations, departments, community groups, healthcare practice groups, etc.

constraint.human: The organization SHALL at least have a name or an id, and possibly more than one

element.short: ODS code to identify the organisation at organisation level
element.definition: Identifier for the organization that is used to identify the organization across multiple disparate systems.
element.requirements: Organizations are known by a variety of ids. Some institutions maintain several, and most collect identifiers for exchange with other organizations concerning the organization.

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comments: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The namespace for the identifier
element.definition: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
element.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers.  To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular sequence or set of unique identifiers.
element.exampleUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the Identifier.value itself is a full uri

element.short: The value that is unique
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comments: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comments: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: Whether the organization's record is still in active use
element.definition: Whether the organization's record is still in active use.
element.comments: Default is true.
element.requirements: Need a flag to indicate a record is no longer to be used and should generally be hidden for the user in the UI.

mapping.map: ./Status (however this concept in ServD more covers why the organization is active or not, could be delisted, deregistered, not operational yet) this could alternatively be derived from ./StartDate and ./EndDate and given a context date.

element.short: The kind of organization that this is.
element.definition: The kind of organization that this is.
element.comments: Organizations can be corporations, wards, sections, clinical teams, government departments, etc. Note that code is generally a classifier of the type of organization; in many applications, codes are used to identity a particular organization (say, ward) as opposed to another of the same type - these are identifiers, not codes.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the kind of organization that this is - different organization types have different uses.

element.short: A code taken from the organisation type list of codes.
element.definition: A code taken from the organisation type list of codes.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the terminology system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the terminology system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: Name used for the organization associated with the ODS code
element.definition: Name used for the organization associated with the ODS code.
element.requirements: Need to use the name as the label of the organization.

element.short: A contact detail for the organization
element.definition: A contact detail for the organization
element.comments: The use code home is not to be used. Note that these contacts are not the contact details of people who are employed by or represent the organization, but official contacts for the organization itself.
element.requirements: Human contact for the organization

constraint.human: The telecom of an organization can never be of use 'home'

element.short: phone | fax | email | pager | other
element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.

element.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

element.short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. Contacts are ranked with lower values coming before higher values.
element.comments: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

element.short: An address for the organization
element.definition: An address for the organization
element.comments: Organization may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods. The use code home is not to be used.
element.requirements: May need to keep track of the organization's addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements.

constraint.human: An address of an organization can never be of use 'home'

mapping.map: No authoritative equivalent in V2.x; some V2.x segments such as OBX might provide a serialized instance value

element.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

element.short: Text representation of the address
element.definition: A full text representation of the address
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc.
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.short: Name of city, town etc.
element.definition: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.

element.short: District name (aka county)
element.definition: The name of the administrative area (county).
element.comments: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' in used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.

element.short: Sub-unit of country (abbreviations ok)
element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).

element.short: Postal code for area
element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.

element.short: The organization of which this organization forms a part
element.definition: The organization of which this organization forms a part.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the hierarchy of organizations within an organization.

element.short: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose
element.definition: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose.
element.comments: Where multiple contacts for the same purpose are provided there is a standard extension that can be used to determine which one is the preferred contact to use.
element.requirements: Need to keep track of assigned contact points within bigger organization.

element.short: The type of contact
element.definition: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached.
element.requirements: Need to distinguish between multiple contact persons.

binding.description: The purpose for which you would contact a contact party

element.short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. Contacts are ranked with lower values coming before higher values.
element.comments: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

element.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

element.short: Text representation of the address
element.definition: A full text representation of the address.
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.
element.exampleString: 1, Main Street, Leeds, West Yorkshire, LS1 3PO

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc.
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.short: Name of city, town etc.
element.definition: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.

element.short: District name (aka county)
element.definition: The name of the administrative area (county).
element.comments: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' in used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.

element.short: Sub-unit of country (abbreviations ok)
element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).

element.short: Postal code for area
element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.

element.short: Country (can be ISO 3166 3 letter code)
element.definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
element.comments: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.
